text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits revised IRM 8.22.9, Closing and Post Closing Actions, incorporating Appeals Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0820-0015, Automated Offer in Compromise (AOIC) Generated Form 7249 and Electronic Public Inspection File (PIF), Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) Guidance.
See the table below for material changes in this IRM:

IRM Title and Brief Description IRM 8.22.9.4.3.3, Acceptance - At (1), incorporated IGM AP-08- Counsel Review Not Required 0820-0015, to include a redacted, AOIC generated Form 7249. IRM 8.22.9.4.3.4, Acceptance - At (2), incorporated IGM AP-08- Counsel Review Required 0820-0015 to include a redacted, AOIC generated Form 7249.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 8.22.9 dated August 26, 2020, is superseded. This revision incorporates Appeals Interim Guidance Memo- randum AP-08-0820-0015, Automated Offer in Compromise (AOIC) Generated Form 7249 and Electronic Public Inspection File (PIF), Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) Guidance.
Appeals Officers, Appeals Account Resolution Specialists and Appeals Team Managers

The Appeals Team Manager (ATM) has approval authority for all CDP closures
The Appeals Team Manager (ATM) has approval authority for all CDP except:
Son of Boss (SOB) liabilities • Offers in Compromise (OIC) that require a higher level of approval under IRM

) Audience: The primary users of this IRM section are ATEs and Appeals Team Managers (ATMs) handling CDP, EH and RJ cases. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Case and Operations Support. (
) Program Owner: Director, Policy, Planning, Quality and Analysis (PPQ&A). (

) Contact Information: Appeals Employees should follow established on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM section. (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
) created Collection Due Process (CDP) appeal rights and with them, the ability for taxpayers to contest their liability under certain circumstances.
Offers in Compromise (OIC) that require a higher level of approval under IRM 1.2.2.6, Delegation Order 5-1 (Rev. 5).
Audience: The primary users of this IRM section are ATEs and Appeals Team Managers (ATMs) handling CDP, EH and RJ cases.

and
are the primary of authority, in addition to applicable Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Further, the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, IRC
), applies to Appeals employees’ interactions with taxpayers. (
) The Policy analyst shown as the originator on the Product Catalog page is assigned author of this IRM. (
) PPQ&A provides trend and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. (
) See IRM Exhibit
, Common Terms and Acronyms used in Collection Due Process, for such common terms and their deﬁnitions. (

) Your decision in a timely CDP case may be subject to Tax Court review. a taxpayer petitions Tax Court, the Court reviews the administrative record Record compiled in making your determination. If the administrative record is plete, the CDP may be remanded for reconsideration. (

) Regardless of the format of the administrative record (paper, electronic, or a hybrid of the two), at closing, the record should include the following: • Final Notice of Determination (NOD) and any Supplemental NOD (if plicable) • ACM/attachments to the NOD • Case Activity Record (CAR), including hand-written notes maintained separately from the CAR • Final Form
• CDP hearing request and envelope(if available) • CDP lien/levy notice (Letter
, Letter

, etc.). -F, Form etc.) and related documentation • Forms
-L and/or

) When closing a CDP case with a credit report: a. Summarize your review of the report in the case activity record, and b. Remove and destroy the credit report prior to submitting the case for closure. (
) The disposition of credit reports by IRS personnel is monitored under The Credit Reporting Act,
U.S.C.

) When a separate Work Unit Number (WUNO) is established for a non- precluded liability issue in CDP, both WUNOs must be closed together to same Account and Processing Support (APS) location unless one is withdrawn. APS holds the case ﬁles together until the suspense periods expires or the matter is resolved in Tax Court. (
) The related WUNO may be an interest abatement, innocent spouse, compromise or other CDP-related liability issue. (
) CDP and interest abatement WUNOs must have separate administrative due to different closing actions required for each. These ﬁles must be together unless one is withdrawn. (

) At the conclusion of the CDP hearing, issue one of the combination letters below. A combination letter must be used as it provides the taxpayer with extended period to petition Tax Court on the interest abatement issue.
Timely CDP Letter
- Notice of Determination Concerning Collection Action(s) Under IRC
and/or IRC
and Abatement of Interest Under IRC
EH Letter
- Decision Letter Concerning Equivalent Hearing Under Section
and/or
of the Internal Revenue Code and Abatement of Interest Under Section
) CDP and Innocent Spouse (IS) WUNOs must have separate administrative ﬁles due to different closing actions required for each. These ﬁles must be closed together unless one is withdrawn. (
) When a joint CDP request includes IS as an issue, each spouse receives a different closing letter because: • The requesting spouse (RS) has
days to petition Tax Court the IS determination
The RS and non-requesting spouse (NRS) each have 30 days to petition Tax Court regarding the CDP determination

) Your decision to reject the OIC is conveyed in the attachment to the CDP determination/decision letter or other closing letter. Your attachment must plicitly state the OIC was rejected and the reason for the rejection including discussion of Reasonable Collection Potential (RCP) when RCP is the the rejection. If the OIC is not clearly rejected, it may lead to a deemed tance under IRC section
(f). Note: In the event an OIC is not agreed to and the case is settled with a agreed resolution that includes a Form

waiver, the narrative the OIC may be brief. However, the brief narrative must clearly state the position of the offer and include all offer periods. Note: If the expiration of the TIPRA statute is imminent, consider issuing a separate Letter

, Offer in Compromise Rejection, rejecting the offer directly to the taxpayer so that the TIPRA statute is protected. Be sure to include all offer periods if such a letter is issued, not just the CDP See IRM
) Once the above documents are complete and assembled, update ACDS status to ’AC/FR’ and submit the CDP and OIC case ﬁles together to your for approval. (

(e), Review, of the proposed rejection is satisﬁed by the ATM review of the ﬁle closing. (

) The withdrawal of the OIC must be discussed in the attachment to the CDP determination/decision letter or other closing letter to close the OIC and the TIPRA statute. Include in the attachment or closing letter all periods that included in the offer. Internal Revenue Manual

Note: Letter 5197, Offer in Compromise Rejection, may be used but, generally, only in TIPRA related circumstances. See (2), Note 2, below.

) Your decision to reject the OIC is conveyed in the attachment to the CDP determination/decision letter or other closing letter. Your attachment must ex- plicitly state the OIC was rejected and the reason for the rejection including a discussion of Reasonable Collection Potential (RCP) when RCP is the basis of the rejection. If the OIC is not clearly rejected, it may lead to a deemed accep- tance under IRC section

(2) Your decision to reject the OIC is conveyed in the attachment to the CDP determination/decision letter or other closing letter. Your attachment must ex- plicitly state the OIC was rejected and the reason for the rejection including a discussion of Reasonable Collection Potential (RCP) when RCP is the basis the rejection. If the OIC is not clearly rejected, it may lead to a deemed tance under IRC section 7122(f).

) Route an OIC that requires Counsel review following the procedures at IRM

) If an offer is rejected due to an unfavorable review by Counsel, explain in the ACM and case activity record why Counsel declined to sign and why rejected the OIC. Note: If an offer receives a review by Counsel that does not support acceptance, the offer may still be accepted by Appeals. See IRM
, Counsel Review of Acceptance Recommendations. (
) A closing letter is prepared for every CDP/EH with the exception of CDPs that did not receive an Appeals Substantive Contact letter. The letters used are discussed below. (

) Any notice required to be sent by statute is sent separately to each ﬁling a joint return. When one joint hearing is requested for both individuals a joint return, the following closing letters are addressed jointly but mailed separately to each individual requesting the joint hearing: • Notices of Determination (NOD) • Decision Letter • Letter
Supplemental NOD (
) Closing letters not required by statute are sent separately to each spouse if one is living at a different address. Examples include: • Letter

) Print an ENMOD or INOLES at closing to ensure the closing letter is mailed the taxpayer’s most current address. (

) Appeals may disregard any portion or all of the CDP or EH hearing request when a portion or all the request states a position which the Service has publicly identiﬁed as frivolous or reﬂects a desire to delay or impede the ad- ministration of the federal tax laws. The entire CDP request may be disregarded and the taxpayer denied a CDP hearing only if the taxpayer to raise a single non-frivolous argument. See IRM
, Frivolous Issues. (
) If a taxpayer fails to respond within
days or responds with frivolous or desire-to-delay statements after receiving Letter
, Frivolous ment, then use Letter
, Disregard Frivolous, to advise the taxpayer the hearing request has been disregarded. (
) An attachment is not prepared for Letter
since Appeals did not legal and administrative analysis. (
) When you reach an agreed resolution and the taxpayer signs Form
, Summary Notice of Determination, prepare Letter
as a cover letter. letter acknowledges receipt of Form
and the agreed resolution of the CDP. Note: When the taxpayer concedes the CDP matter and consents to the ﬁled or levy action, a Form
should not be secured. A withdrawal from hearing request should be solicited. (
) Document the agreement reached on either Form
or Letter

including the terms of the agreed resolution: • IA: payment amount and date • OIC: terms of the accepted offer • CNC: accrual of interest and penalty • Innocent Spouse: the ﬁnal determination • Penalty and/or Interest abatement: the ﬁnal determination Note: This list is not all inclusive. (
) If you considered an OIC prior to reaching agreement on an IA or CNC, must state whether the offer was rejected, returned or withdrawn in to end the TIPRA statute. (

is signed by the ATM with the following exceptions noted below. Delegation Order App-
allows Appeals Officers, Settlement Officers or Account Resolution Specialists to sign Form
and Letter

) If a taxpayer withdraws from a CDP hearing but then rescinds that prior to formal issuance of the closing letter by Appeals, proceed with the hearing. The rescission by the taxpayer may be made verbally or in Document the CAR. (

) Determination Letters contain a Summary Statement at the bottom of the which: a. Brieﬂy states whether the disputed collection action is sustained or not Example: “The ﬁling of the Notice of Federal Tax Lien was appropriate. The lien will remain in place until the liability is satisﬁed or collection statute of limitation expires” b. Describes any conditions that might result in future enforced collection action Example: “Your request for an installment agreement is granted. and Post Closing Actions
) If a CDP liability is paid and the taxpayer doesn’t withdraw their request, still must issue a determination letter. (

) Determination and decision letters are issued with an attachment which provides the taxpayer a substantive discussion of the CDP hearing. Avoid to erencing computer codes by their number or description (i.e. TC
, and and using acronyms the taxpayer won’t be familiar with. Letters (
) In an abuse of discretion review, the Tax Court relies on your attachment decide if your determination was arbitrary, capricious, or without sound fact or law. (

) The attachment may be prepared in APGolf by selecting “Attachment” from CDP pick list. Other formats are acceptable as long as they generally the same layout and contain the information noted in the sections below. (

) At the start of the attachment, list the type of tax, period(s), date of the notice(s), and date of taxpayer’s CDP request. List all periods that Periods the CDP notice(s). If an OIC was considered in CDP, separately indicate in attachment all periods that were included in the OIC. (
) State whether you conducted a levy or lien hearing, or a combination of (
) If the request was based on both lien and levy notices, specify tax and listed in each notice. (
) If the tax includes civil penalty module(s), specify the code section under the penalty was imposed. (
) Tax periods from related WUNOs may be combined into a single NOD or Decision Letter if they are for the same taxpayer or taxpayer entity. (
) This section brieﬂy summarizes what the reader will ﬁnd in the rest of the document. Clearly state what your determination is regarding the hearing. and (

) The brief background section of the attachment discusses: • Requests for documentation, how much time the taxpayer had to produce the documents and whether they were provided • Whether a conference was held and, if so, the type of conference, as in-person, telephone, etc. See IRM

, Types of Appeals Conferences, for information on the different types of Appeals ences • Any issues regarding timeliness of the CDP request. If timeliness disputed by the taxpayer, discuss this further in “Issues” section (

) You are required by law to consider three areas in a CDP determination, referred to as the “Big Three.” Your attachment must contain a “Big Three” Review review that includes: a. Veriﬁcation the requirements of any applicable law or administrative procedure were met
S (
) Internal Revenue Manual
This section brieﬂy summarizes what the reader will ﬁnd in the rest of the document. Clearly state what your determination is regarding the hearing.

Valid and Accurate Assessment: Was a valid and accurate assessment made for each tax and period on the CDP notice? Invalid or inaccurate as- sessments must be abated and collection cannot proceed. If the liability arose from a Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency (SNOD) or Letter
, Proposed Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Notiﬁcation, discuss whether the notice was properly issued as per IRM
, Legal and Administrative (L&A) Procedure Review. Discussion should include whether:
• The assessment is valid because the SNOD or
was timely by certiﬁed mail to the taxpayer’s last known address • The assessment is valid because the taxpayer signed a waiver, the SNOD or
unnecessary. • The assessment is invalid because the SNOD or

was not sent the last known address and not received in sufficient time to petition Court • The assessment is invalid because the assessment was incorrectly assessed under math error procedures with no SNOD • For

This section is for discussing all non-frivolous issues raised on Form
and in the hearing. The table below highlights the issues a taxpayer might raise and what to discuss:
Any spousal defense raised and why the claim was accepted or rejected.
Any challenges to the appropriateness of collection action raised including:
Economic hardship: If the taxpayer claims levy action will result in an economic hardship, discuss why this is or isn’t so. Levy action is prohib

ited if it would cause economic hardship even if the taxpayer has unﬁled returns. If you ﬁnd economic hardship, place the CDP periods in CNC hardship status. Discuss that penalties and interest continue to accrue and the account may be removed from CNC status if their ﬁnancial situation improves.
Taxes discharged in bankruptcy: If the taxpayer claims the tax liability was discharged in bankruptcy, discuss why this is or isn’t so

the issue is... Then discuss... alternatives Any collection alternatives raised including IA, OIC, posting a bond, substitution of other asset, withholding collection action and withdrawal of an NFTL. • For an IA, discuss the terms of agreement and actions required. Advise the taxpayer of the consequences if the terms are not met or if there is a change in their ﬁnancial situation • For an NFTL withdrawal request, discuss the issue using one of the four withdrawal criteria in IRC

(j) • For accepted OICs, do not record the details of the RCP as they are instead listed in a separate ACM • For rejected OICs, provide a detailed RCP so the taxpayer will know the reason for the rejection. Also, clearly state the OIC was rejected and the reason for the rejection. Challenges Any liability challenge made by the taxpayer. • Discuss whether the taxpayer was precluded from raising liability and why • If liability was at issue, explain why adjustments requested by the taxpayer were accepted or rejected • If you considered a liability that was precluded from CDP, your attach- ment will only describe the adjustments to the liability. A liability precluded from CDP is not addressed in the attachment except to note that liability was addressed separately from the CDP • If there is no challenge to the liability, state “The taxpayer did not dispute the liability” (
) If the taxpayer’s arguments and/or collection alternatives were rejected, were they rejected? Explain in detail why your determination was correct. (

) If the taxpayer or representative listed issues in the request for Appeal that were not pursued while the case was in Appeals, note that in your ACM general statement such as : No other issues were pursued by the taxpayer / representative while in

collection alternatives raised including IA, OIC, posting a bond, substitution other asset, withholding collection action and withdrawal of an NFTL. For an IA, discuss the terms of agreement and actions required. Advise the taxpayer of the consequences if the terms are not met or if there is a change in their ﬁnancial situation For an NFTL withdrawal request, discuss the issue using one of the four withdrawal criteria in IRC

(j) For accepted OICs, do not record the details of the RCP as they are instead listed in a separate ACM For rejected OICs, provide a detailed RCP so the taxpayer will know the reason for the rejection. Also, clearly state the OIC was rejected and the reason for the rejection.

In the request for the appeal, the taxpayer seeks alternatives such as: OIC, CNC, IA, and interest and penalty abatement. However, at confer- ence, only an OIC is discussed and the case is ultimately resolved with an OIC. There is no need to address any other of the original proposed alternatives other than as stated above.
When an ASFR/SFR liability was raised by the taxpayer, document the following under Issues Raised or on the Form 12257:

You ﬁled income tax return(s) for calendar year ending [ ] with Appeals after the completed substitute return(s) for you as authorized by Internal Revenue Code 6020(b). Appeals forwarded your income tax return(s) for reconsideration. The IRS processed your return(s) and made the adjustments you requested. Since there is no dispute as to the amount of the tax liability, it is not necessary for Appeals to make a determination on this issue.
When an ASFR/SFR liability was raised by the taxpayer but document the following under Issues Raised or on the Form 12257:

I determined you were precluded from challenging the liability for the [ ] tax in CDP because you received a prior opportunity to do so. Though precluded, liability was reconsidered outside of CDP. You ﬁled an income tax return for the [ ] tax year(s) which were forwarded for reconsideration. The IRS made the adjust- ments you requested.

Appeals does not consider frivolous issues. In the balancing section, explain whether the proposed collection action balances the need for efficient collection of taxes with the legitimate concern of the taxpayer that any collection action be no more intrusive than necessary. Balancing is tied to the taxpayer’s: a. Actions or inaction b. Compliance history c. Financial circumstance
Discuss balancing even when the only issue raised is liability.

Having conﬁrmed the validity of the underlying liability, the IRS has little choice but to collect your tax liability as best it can until you decide to voluntarily pay. It is my judgment that the Notice of Intent to Levy balances the efficient collection of taxes with your legitimate concern that the collection action be no more intrusive than necessary.
When the taxpayer is unresponsive or proposes no collection alternatives, the levy proposed or Notice of Federal Tax Lien is generally sustained.

You proposed no alternative to the Notice of Federal Tax Lien and you did not participate in the hearing you requested. It is my judgment that the Notice of Federal Tax Lien balances the efficient collection of taxes with your legitimate concern that the collection action be no more intrusive than necessary. When the tax liability is paid in full or expires by statute, the lien will be released.

While the Notice of Intent to Levy was properly issued, you subsequently provided ﬁnancial information to Appeals that conﬁrmed levy would result in economic hardship. Appeals has agreed to put your account into Currently not Collectible status.

The ﬁling of the Federal Tax Lien makes the IRS a secured creditor, which protects the Government in the event that you sell assets or ﬁle bankruptcy. You failed to demonstrate that the Notice of Federal Tax Lien was overly intrusive or that better alternatives are available. It is my judgment that the Notice of Federal Tax Lien balanced the efficient col
lection of taxes with your legitimate concern that the collection action be no more intrusive than necessary.

impartial Appeals officer or an employee who had no prior involvement with this and tax period(s) conducted your hearing, unless you waived that right. Appeals veriﬁed that applicable laws and administrative procedures have been met, has the issues raised, and has balanced the proposed Collection action with

“An impartial Appeals officer or an employee who had no prior involvement with tax and tax period(s) conducted your hearing, unless you waived that right. has veriﬁed that applicable laws and administrative procedures have been met, considered the issues raised, and has balanced the proposed Collection action the legitimate concerns that such action be no more intrusive than necessary as required by section 6330(c)(3). The taxpayer(s) has (have) represented to Appeals that the taxpayer(s) agrees with the proposed collection alternative described The proposed collection alternative balances the need for the efficient collection of taxes with the legitimate concern of the person that any collection action be no more intrusive than necessary. The determination of Appeals is: [Insert terms of collection alternative]”.

EH cases are closed using one of the following closing codes:
Closing Deﬁnition Code 13 disregarded CDP request • 14 fully sustained • collection action is supported with no change

Closing Deﬁnition Code • 15 partially or not sustained • full or partial abatement • minor changes or collection action is completely overturned 16 withdrawal 20 withdrawal with no Appeals time (3) RJ cases are closed using one of the following closing codes: Closing Deﬁnition Code 14 Whether the Collection function is following Appeals determination: Collection is following Appeals deter- mination 14 Change in circumstances: No change in Appeals de- termination 15 Collection is not following Appeals’ determination 16 CDP determination is revised in cases involving change in circumstances
RJ cases are closed using one of the following closing codes:

Closing Deﬁnition Code 14 Whether the Collection function is following Appeals determination: Collection is following Appeals deter- mination 14 Change in circumstances: No change in Appeals de- termination 15 Collection is not following Appeals’ determination 16 CDP determination is revised in cases involving change in circumstances

(08-26-2020) Taxpayer Contact after Determination or Decision Issued
) Appeals cannot rescind a Notice of Determination (NOD) in any Appeals may amend or revise a NOD within the
day period to petition a Court if: a. The NOD is clearly in error b. The taxpayer has not petitioned Tax Court c. The correction can be made within the

day period to petition Tax Court Example: The summary statement on the determination letter says levy action is appropriate while the attachment to the determination says the is to be placed in CNC. The hearing officer meant to say that levy was not appropriate because the account should be placed in CNC. NOD is clearly in error and should be corrected if the
day period to petitioned Tax Court has not expired. (
) If the time remaining within the

day period to petition Tax Court is not cient to determine if the NOD was in error, do not amend or revise the NOD. Example: The taxpayer timely submitted ﬁnancial information that was not ated with the case before the NOD was mailed. It is not clear if the additional information would have changed the determination. (
) If the error is not correctable within the

day period to petition Tax Court, not amend or revise the NOD. Example: The taxpayer submitted an offer directly to COIC before the NOD was mailed and the offer was not associated with the CDP. Investigating an offer will take more than
days. (
) An amended or revised NOD must contain the same date as the original The NOD should be titled “Revised” and issued by certiﬁed mail. (
) Consult with counsel if it is not clear whether an amended or revised nation is appropriate. (

) If Collection disagrees with Appeals determination in CDP, they may express their disagreement to local Appeals management after the case is closed of Appeals and returned. Such discussions are delayed until after a case is returned to prevent prohibited ex parte communications, preserve the dence of Appeals, and protect the integrity of the CDP process. (
) If a resolution cannot be reached at the local level, the disagreement may elevated via the process found at IRM
, Disagreements to Determinations. (

) The Appeals determination in a timely CDP or EH must be implemented if Collection disagrees and the disagreement is elevated. The purpose of raising or elevating a disagreement is not to overturn Appeals determination but to ensure similar concerns do not arise in the future.
The NOD is clearly in error The taxpayer has not petitioned Tax Court The correction can be made within the
day period to petition Tax Court

The summary statement on the determination letter says levy action is appropriate while the attachment to the determination says the account is to be placed in CNC. The hearing officer meant to say that levy action was not appropriate because the account should be placed in CNC. The NOD is clearly in error and should be corrected if the 30 day period to petitioned Tax Court has not expired.
If the time remaining within the 30 day period to petition Tax Court is not suffi- cient to determine if the NOD was in error, do not amend or revise the NOD.
The taxpayer submitted an offer directly to COIC before the NOD was mailed and the offer was not associated with the CDP. Investigating an offer will take more than 30 days.

A Tax Court case is commenced by ﬁling a petition. The table below lists the deadline for ﬁling a petition with the Tax Court:

Deadline IRC 30 days from issuance of Notice of Determina- 6320/6330 tion 90 days from issuance of Notice of Determina- 6015(e) tion • For claims ﬁled after December 18, 2015: 6404(h) Any time after the earlier of the date the notice of determination denying interest abatement is issued or the date which is 180 days after the date the taxpayer ﬁles the interest abatement claim. If a notice of determination is issued, a petition must be be ﬁled within 180 days after the date of issuance. • For claims ﬁled on or before December 18, 2015: 180 days from issuance of Notice of Determination.
petition within
calendar days of the issuance of the Notice of Determination. (
USC

) prohibits the ﬁling of a petition with the Tax Court if a taxpayer is in bankruptcy. If a taxpayer petitions Tax Court after ﬁling a bank- ruptcy petition, the Tax Court petition will be dismissed. In innocent spouse and CDP cases where the taxpayer has ﬁled a bankruptcy petition, the deadline for ﬁling a petition with the Tax Court is suspended for the period during which the taxpayer is prohibited by the bankruptcy from ﬁling such petition, plus
days (applicable to Tax Court petitions ﬁled after December
) IRC
) does not provide additional time to petition to persons residing
Note: Special extensions may be available for members of the Armed Forces serving in a combat zone/contingency. See IRC 7508(a).

The standard of review is... The scope of the review is... • is at de novo (anew) for the liability With respect to the liability issues, the issue. court is not limited to reviewing the • abuse of discretion for other ad- record before Appeals and may hold a ministrative determinations trial and take new evidence and testimony. is not at abuse of discretion The administrative record. (
) “Abuse of discretion” is deﬁned as “arbitrary, capricious, clearly unlawful, or without sound basis in fact or law.” (

) The Tax Court may remand a case to Appeals when: • Appeals abused its discretion, or • The taxpayer was not given a proper hearing, or • The administrative record is insufficient for the Tax Court to properly evaluate the case (

) Counsel may request a remand if there is a signiﬁcant, non-harmless error the case cannot be defended. In such instances, Counsel may ﬁle a Motion Remand in Tax Court. Examples of when remand may be appropriate • Taxpayer requested abatement of interest but Appeals failed to the issue • Appeals rejected the taxpayer’s OIC without considering ﬁnancial mation provided by the taxpayer prior to the issuance of the determination/decision letter • Appeals issued the determination prior to the expiration of an agreed upon deadline for the taxpayer to provide veriﬁcation information • Taxpayer raised liability where liability was not precluded and the Appeals closed the case without addressing liability • Appeals ﬁndings were confusing or contradictory (

) Changed circumstances occurring after the CDP hearing that might affect outcome of the taxpayer’s case are dealt with outside of the CDP process. If taxpayer submits a new issue while the Tax Court case is pending, Counsel may approach Collection per IRM
, Post Petition Investigation, to consider the new issue and input any case resolution. The new issue might include, but is not limited to: • Collection alternatives • CNC • ID theft claim (
) Collection considers the new issue if: • The taxpayer’s circumstances changed since the CDP hearing, or

the issue Appeals rejected the taxpayer’s OIC without considering ﬁnancial mation provided by the taxpayer prior to the issuance of the determination/decision letter Appeals issued the determination prior to the expiration of an agreed upon deadline for the taxpayer to provide veriﬁcation information Taxpayer raised liability where liability was not precluded and the Appeals closed the case without addressing liability Appeals ﬁndings were confusing or contradictory
The taxpayer’s circumstances changed since the CDP hearing, or

• The taxpayer did not respond to Appeals during the CDP hearing illness or travel and is now offering a collection alternative which resolve the case Example: Taxpayer petitions Tax Court and requests an OIC that was not submitted during the CDP hearing. The taxpayer’s circumstances changed. Due to the absence of error by Appeals, Counsel does not request a remand. Instead, Counsel submits Form
to Collection consider and if agreement is reached, Collection inputs the case tion. (

) Remand may be appropriate in rare, unusual situations when there has change in circumstances that is material and affects the core issues in the case such that, if known at the time of the Appeals hearing, would likely altered Appeals’ determination. Such remands should be limited to cases in which the taxpayer: • fully cooperated • submitted all requested and available evidence within the taxpayer’s control (

) The harmless error rule provides that a court should not ﬁnd an abuse of cretion if the mistake causes no prejudice or does not affect the ultimate determination. This rule is often applied where the taxpayer makes only frivolous or groundless arguments. Counsel evaluates errors to determine whether they are harmless. (

) When a CDP is remanded, the Counsel attorney prepares a memorandum addressed to Appeals explaining: a. The reasons why the court remanded the case b. Any special requirements in the order c. What issues the court has ordered Appeals to address on remand Note: The Counsel attorney provides a copy of this memorandum to the representative. (

and IRM

) Send a secure e-mail to APS requesting input of: a. Closing code

ﬁeld. (

) Remands must be expeditiously worked to meet court-ordered deadlines conducting the supplemental hearing and responding to the court. These deadlines are found in the Area Counsel memorandum accompanying the remand. (
) In a docketed case, the taxpayer’s counsel of record should solely receive correspondence as stated in
CFR
) Contact the taxpayer or counsel of record, as needed, to schedule the mental hearing. Ask if a copy of Counsel’s memorandum to Appeals the remand was provided, and give them a copy if it was not. (

) Notwithstanding the expedited nature of a remand assignment, be certain enough attention and consideration are given to the issues discussed in remand order and that they are adequately presented to the taxpayer, larly when the taxpayer is pro se. (

) Complete the requirements in Counsel’s remand memo including Counsel by the speciﬁed due dates. Do not address issues that are outside the scope of the remand. If anything is unclear, be sure to address any cations to the memo with Counsel. (

) Depending on the requirements stated in the remand, new information may necessary to be obtained from the taxpayer. Discuss with Counsel the priateness of issuing an ARI to Collection to obtain, review and/or and comment on new information. (

) Avoid the hasty issuance of a supplemental notice of determination. Be with granting reasonable extensions of time for the taxpayer to complete requirements of the remand. If extensions will go beyond a deadline stated the remand order or Counsel memo, consult with IRS Counsel regarding extension. (
) When the Tax Court remands a CDP for consideration of an OIC not in the initial hearing, follow IRM
, Offers in Compromise (OICs), New carding in and processing the OIC. (

) After the Supplemental NOD is issued, the jurisdiction of the case remains the Tax Court. The Supplemental NOD is not a new determination and does not provide the taxpayer with additional judicial appeal rights. (

When the Tax Court remands a CDP for reconsideration of an OIC, Appeals reconsiders the original offer. The taxpayer is not asked to submit a new OIC, pay a new application fee or make a new TIPRA payment. However, if the amount is increased, the taxpayer must make an additional payment of 20% of
The original rejection of the offer in the CDP hearing tolls the TIPRA statute under IRC 7122(f) even if the court holds the rejection was erroneous.

After the Supplemental NOD is issued, the jurisdiction of the case remains with the Tax Court. The Supplemental NOD is not a new determination and does not provide the taxpayer with additional judicial appeal rights.

Under section
, comment (a) of the Restatement
d of Contracts, false information or concealment may allow the IRS to rescind an accepted offer. To do so, the IRS must be able to show that: (
) the misrepresentation was material; (
) the misrepresenta- tion induced the IRS to accept the offer; and (
) the IRS was justiﬁed in relying on the misrepresentation.
